Summary: The proposal introduces a framework for geometric deep learning, addressing limitations of existing GNNs in scalability, expressive power, and generalization across non-Euclidean domains. It combines geometric priors with adaptive computation and includes a detailed experiment plan.
Strengths: Clear problem statement with well-identified limitations of existing GNNs.
Strong motivation grounded in prior work.
Ambitious and comprehensive proposed method with three distinct components.
Detailed and well-designed experiment plan covering synthetic benchmarks to real-world applications.
Weaknesses: Lacks technical depth in explaining the implementation of unified geometric architectures.
Scalability claims are optimistic given the complexity of the proposed methods.
Feasibility of integrating all three components into a cohesive framework is questionable.
Limited discussion of potential pitfalls and technical challenges.
Questions: How will the unified geometric architectures be implemented in practice?
What are the specific technical challenges in integrating the three proposed components?
How will the proposed methods handle extremely large graphs in real-world applications?
What are the fallback options if any of the proposed components fail to deliver the expected improvements?
Limitations: Potential high computational cost of the proposed methods.
Complexity of integrating multiple adaptive mechanisms into a single framework.
Risk of overfitting on synthetic benchmarks without sufficient real-world validation.
